overall_score_comment: Like a rom-com written by someone who's never actually spoken to their crush—adorable, but deeply confused about how reality works.
the_roast:
Let's talk about that opening, shall we? 'I threw a wish in the well / Don't ask me, I'll never tell' followed immediately by telling us EVERYTHING for the next three minutes. That's not mysterious, that's just bad at keeping secrets. And then she trades her soul for a wish? Girl, you already made the wish in the well! That's double-dipping on the supernatural transaction fees. Pick a lane: are we doing fountain wishes or Faustian bargains?

The real lyrical masterpiece here is 'Before you came into my life, I missed you so bad.' Let's just pause and appreciate the philosophical quandary of missing someone before you met them. That's not love at first sight, that's a time travel paradox. Did you miss him, or did you miss the IDEA of him? Because those are different things, and one of them requires significantly less therapy. 'I missed you so, so bad'—she says this FOUR times as if repetition will make it make sense. Spoiler alert: it doesn't.

And can we address the commitment issues? 'Here's my number, so call me maybe'? MAYBE?! You just told this man you traded your soul and missed him before meeting him, but now it's 'maybe'? That's like proposing marriage and ending with 'if you're not busy.' Either you're willing to make interdimensional wishes for this dude or you're not. The emotional whiplash here could cause insurance claims.

lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to take Economics 101 before making any more supernatural deals

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: You gave me nothing at all / But still you're in my way
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Continuing to be obsessed with someone who gives you nothing
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Court-ordered self-help books and a subscription to a healthy boundaries podcast

hidden_meanings: Clearly, this is an allegory about the modern gig economy where workers offer their souls for pennies and dimes while maintaining plausible deniability with 'maybe.' The ripped jeans represent the tattered social safety net, and the hot wind blowing is obviously capitalism. Or it's just about a girl who saw a cute boy and completely forgot how phones, time, and human communication work.
final_verdict: A delightfully catchy monument to romantic indecision and questionable grasp of causality. It's the musical equivalent of shooting your shot while simultaneously hedging all your bets—bold, confusing, and somehow it worked anyway.
title: Call Me Maybe
